Balagundi Star project, detailed structural mapping over the tenements at 1:3000 scale 
 and generated targets for further investigation and follow-up work. 
 The Balagundi Star project is located approximately 22km east of Kalgoorlie, 
 Western Australia (Fig. 1),  on the Kurnalpi 1:250 000 and Kanowna 1:100 000 
 mapsheets.  The Balagundi Star project comprises tenements P25/1186 to P25/1188 
 TOPOGRAPHY AND ACCESS 
 The Balagundi Star project is accessed via the sealed Bulong Road thence by various 
 exploration tracks and gridlines throughout most of the project area.  Topography is

31.text: The geology of the Balagundi Star project is dominated by thin colluvial cover with

32.text: common bedrock exposures.  Bedrock geology comprises a thick sequence of steeply-

33.text: W-WSW-dipping shales and wackes which have been intruded by mafic and

34.text: intermediate intrusive bodies such as dolerite and andesitic porphyrys.

37.text: During the reporting period EGMC conducted an open-file data review of the project

38.text: area, detailed 1:3000 scale structural mapping and combined the results to generate

39.text: targets for review and planning of follow-up work.

text:
The geology of the Balagundi Star project is dominated by thin colluvial cover with 
 common bedrock exposures.  Bedrock geology comprises a thick sequence of steeply-
 W-WSW-dipping shales and wackes which have been intruded by mafic and 
 intermediate intrusive bodies such as dolerite and andesitic porphyrys. 
 5.0  WORK COMPLETED 
 During the reporting period EGMC conducted an open-file data review of the project 
 area, detailed 1:3000 scale structural mapping and combined the results to generate 
 targets for review and planning of follow-up work.

27.text: The Balagundi Star project experiences warm to hot summers and cool, dry winters.

28.text: Rainfall is generally around 200mm a year.

text:
The Balagundi Star project experiences warm to hot summers and cool, dry winters.  
 Rainfall is generally around 200mm a year.

14.text: Target A: Located along the western contact between known dolerites and a suspected

15.text: mafic unit to the west. Contact interpreted as a shear zone based upon a prominent

16.text: NW trending aeromagnetic low along the interpreted contact. Regolith appears to be

17.text: largely unfavorable for soil sampling (pisolitic colluvium and indurated transported

18.text: gravel deposits dominate the area). No drilling to date. Specifically aim to target

19.text: faults that cross-cut the interpreted contact shear zone.

21.text: Target B: Located along sheared eastern contact of a dolerite sill. Contact shear zone

22.text: known to host anomalous Au mineralisation near surface and at depth (eg. in

23.text: BARC001). Not well tested with drilling. Workings and dry blowings located at

24.text: northern end of target zone, together with additional Au anomalism in shallow

25.text: drilling. Strong Au and As soils anomalism at southern end.

27.text: Target C: Located along sheared(?) western contact of dolerite sill. This same contact

28.text: is known to be well mineralised in the vicinity of the Mt Bellew shaft and is largely

29.text: untested by drilling south of the Bulong Road. Specifically focus on targeting cross-

30.text: cutting structures intersecting the sheared contact zone; includes the Hardrock mining

31.text: area (ca 100 ounces Au produced). However, soil anomalism is low level in this area.

33.text: Target D:  Conceptual target area based upon anomalous NE-oriented aeromagnetic

34.text: trends. Has not been drilled; only one line of soil sampling completed over the target

35.text: zone to date with no Au or As anomalism noted.

37.text: Target E: Conceptual target defined by a zone of multiple intersecting faults

38.text: associated with minor historic workings (western edge of Bank of Ireland

39.text: mineralisation). Stratigraphic anomaly also associated with the target area (absence of

40.text: dolerite across E-W fault zone). No drilling to date. Point soil Au anomaly of 197ppb.

42.text: Target F: Conceptual target defined by intersecting faults and an anomalous NE

43.text: trending and sheared (?) dolerite contact. Associated scrapes and dry blowings occur

44.text: along the NE trend. Limited soil and drill testing completed to date. Best soil anomaly

text:
targets areas are as follows: 
 Target A: Located along the western contact between known dolerites and a suspected 
 mafic unit to the west. Contact interpreted as a shear zone based upon a prominent 
 NW trending aeromagnetic low along the interpreted contact. Regolith appears to be 
 largely unfavorable for soil sampling (pisolitic colluvium and indurated transported 
 gravel deposits dominate the area). No drilling to date. Specifically aim to target 
 faults that cross-cut the interpreted contact shear zone. 
 Target B: Located along sheared eastern contact of a dolerite sill. Contact shear zone 
 known to host anomalous Au mineralisation near surface and at depth (eg. in 
 BARC001). Not well tested with drilling. Workings and dry blowings located at 
 northern end of target zone, together with additional Au anomalism in shallow 
 drilling. Strong Au and As soils anomalism at southern end. 
 Target C: Located along sheared(?) western contact of dolerite sill. This same contact 
 is known to be well mineralised in the vicinity of the Mt Bellew shaft and is largely 
 untested by drilling south of the Bulong Road. Specifically focus on targeting cross-
 cutting structures intersecting the sheared contact zone; includes the Hardrock mining 
 area (ca 100 ounces Au produced). However, soil anomalism is low level in this area.  
 Target D:  Conceptual target area based upon anomalous NE-oriented aeromagnetic 
 trends. Has not been drilled; only one line of soil sampling completed over the target 
 zone to date with no Au or As anomalism noted. 
 Target E: Conceptual target defined by a zone of multiple intersecting faults 
 associated with minor historic workings (western edge of Bank of Ireland 
 mineralisation). Stratigraphic anomaly also associated with the target area (absence of 
 dolerite across E-W fault zone). No drilling to date. Point soil Au anomaly of 197ppb. 
 Target F: Conceptual target defined by intersecting faults and an anomalous NE 
 trending and sheared (?) dolerite contact. Associated scrapes and dry blowings occur 
 along the NE trend. Limited soil and drill testing completed to date. Best soil anomaly 
 Target G: Conceptual target defined by intersection of the Mt Bellew shear (western 
 dolerite contact) with a NE-trending fault known to host Au mineralisation. Numerous 
 scrapes and dry blowings are evident but limited shafts are present (may have been

10.text: Target J: Conceptual target defined by the intersection of targets A, B and C, along

11.text: the southern boundary of P25/1188. There is a weak As in soil anomaly associated

12.text: with this area, but no Au soil anomalism is evident. No drilling to date.

16.text: The targets generated by the combining of geological mapping and open-file data are

17.text: currently being reviewed by EGMC to plan follow-up work

text:
moderately NE-dipping vein system. 
 Target J: Conceptual target defined by the intersection of targets A, B and C, along 
 the southern boundary of P25/1188. There is a weak As in soil anomaly associated 
 with this area, but no Au soil anomalism is evident. No drilling to date. 
 CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS 
 The targets generated by the combining of geological mapping and open-file data are 
 currently being reviewed by EGMC to plan follow-up work
